name: Give TimeoutTest.timeoutFailure more time to pass
creator: Marlene Stamp
description:
The test org.junit.tests.TimeoutTest.timeoutFailure was failing on my laptop with the official 4.1 release as follows:

"""
[java] There was 1 failure:
[java] 1) timeoutFailure(org.junit.tests.TimeoutTest)
[java] java.lang.AssertionError: expected: but was:
[java] at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:69)
[java] at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:333)
[java] at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:101)
[java] at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:112)
[java] at org.junit.tests.TimeoutTest.timeoutFailure(TimeoutTest.java:71)
(...snip...)
"""

I grabbed the latest from CVS and I could also reproduce the problem. Temporarily changing line 71 of TimeoutTest.java to the following:

assertEquals(result.getFailures().get(0).getException().getMessage(), InterruptedException.class, result.getFailures().get(0).getException().getClass());

...exposed that execution was indeed going to line 68 of TestMethodRunner.java and a simple Exception was logged (with addFailure) instead of an InterruptedException.


I remember from my C++ demo coding days that with some operating systems the best granularity you could get with a timer was about 10 milliseconds, so I started fiddling with the test's numbers, in case execution was being switched at just the right time to miss the timeout. Here are the results of my experimentation:

timeout | sleep | result
------------------------
100 | 200 | fail
200 | 400 | fail
250 | 500 | pass
400 | 800 | pass
1000 | 2000 | pass


...and thus this patch sets the timings to 250/500, which will hopefully go unnoticed by anybody running these tests often. I was not able to reproduce the problem on my desktop computer, although it is running a slightly different version: JDK 1.5 Update 7. You guys may even want to crank it to 1000/2000, just to be on the safe side.


Hopefully this won't start a big debate over my laptop being too slow for running JUnit (it's a 2.0 GHz) nor my operating system/software version being suboptimal for it (the problem only manifested itself when running the Ant script on the command line - but not in Eclipse!). FYI, I'm running JDK 1.5 Update 9.

HTH,
- Oli

name: Suite allows for cycles to be created on load
creator: Marlene Stamp
description:
A Suite defined like the following will create a endless cycle of the same Suite classes being loaded and often crash the Java VM:

-- snip --
@org.junit.runner.RunWith(org.junit.runners.Suite.class)
@org.junit.runners.Suite.SuiteClasses({StackOverflowSuite.class, StackOverflowSuite.class})
public class StackOverflowSuite {

}

-- snip --

A possible solution would be to maintain a static list of all suites loaded and ensure that a newly loaded suite is not yet in that list.

Cheers,
Richard Poulin
Tom Burns

rawIssue.dcterms:title: Suite allows for cycles to be created on load

public class StackOverflowSuite {

}

-- snip --

A possible solution would be to maintain a static list of all suites loaded and ensure that a newly loaded suite is not yet in that list.

Cheers,
Richard Poulin
Tom Burns

name: 4.1 missing in maven-metadata.xml on ibiblio
creator: Rick Yuen
description: Version 4.1 is available from ibiblio.org, but is not mentioned in http://www.ibiblio.org/maven2/junit/junit/maven-metadata.xml and therefore Maven still uses version 4.0 if a version range such as [4.0,5.0) is specified.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: 4.1 missing in maven-metadata.xml on ibiblio
rawIssue.dcterms:description: Version 4.1 is available from ibiblio.org, but is not mentioned in http://www.ibiblio.org/maven2/junit/junit/maven-metadata.xml and therefore Maven still uses version 4.0 if a version range such as [4.0,5.0) is specified.

name: Probelm on testing Hibernate in a multi-thread environment
creator: Marlene Stamp
description: I am writing a Java program that uses thread to get Hibernate session to access database. The program works fine. But when I try to test the code in JUnit, the hibernate access code Session s = sessionFactory.openSession(); , which is running inside a thread, will never get return. If I write a main function to run the test code, it works without problem.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: Probelm on testing Hibernate in a multi-thread environment
rawIssue.dcterms:description: I am writing a Java program that uses thread to get Hibernate session to access database. The program works fine. But when I try to test the code in JUnit, the hibernate access code Session s = sessionFactory.openSession(); , which is running inside a thread, will never get return. If I write a main function to run the test code, it works without problem.

name: Error while compiling the Test code.
creator: Jennifer Ginness
description:
I want to Compile my TestCalculator.java

My Source files in C:\JUnit_Test\junitbook\ directory ,

for compiling the TestCalculator.java file i use follwing command , "javac -classpath ../../junit4.1/junit-4.1.jar TestCalculator.java"


C:\junitbook\jumpstart>javac -classpath ../../junit4.1/junit-4.1.jar *.java


It gives follwing error ,

TestCalculator.java:2: cannot access junit.framework.TestCase bad class file: ..\..\junit4.1\junit-4.1.jar(junit/framework/TestCase.class)
class file has wrong version 49.0, should be 48.0
Please remove or make sure it appears in the correct subdirectory of the classpath.
import junit.framework.TestCase;
^
1 error

C:\junit4.1\JUnit_Test\junitbook\jumpstart>


How to resolve this isssue?

Regards,
Jennifer Ginness.

name: JUnit 4 not really backward compatible
creator: Rick Yuen
description:
JUnit 4 claims to be backward compatible. My understanding of this is this means that JUnit 3 tests and suites can be executed without any changes.

However, running a class with a static suite() method is no longer supported: the class needs to be modified and a @RunWith(@Suite) annotation has to be added.

We had several bugs/requests for the Eclipse JUnit launcher in this area.

Any updates planed?

rawIssue.dcterms:title: JUnit 4 not really backward compatible
rawIssue.dcterms:description:
JUnit 4 claims to be backward compatible. My understanding of this is this means that JUnit 3 tests and suites can be executed without any changes.

However, running a class with a static suite() method is no longer supported: the class needs to be modified and a @RunWith(@Suite) annotation has to be added.

We had several bugs/requests for the Eclipse JUnit launcher in this area.

Any updates planed?

name: shows green bar while assert false
creator: Freddy Freund
description:
@Test
public void testMethod() {
assert 1 == 2;
}

this will show the green bar and testMethod passed in eclipse.

name: Ignored method fails
creator: Freddy Freund
description:
If you have parameterized test class, and you pass thorough incorrect number of parameters then even IGNORED method fails.
It causes the following exception trace:

java.lang.Exception: No runnable methods
at org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassMethodsRunner.testAborted(TestClassMethodsRunner.java:42)
at org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassMethodsRunner.invokeTestMethod(TestClassMethodsRunner.java:68)
at org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassMethodsRunner.run(TestClassMethodsRunner.java:35)
at org.junit.internal.runners.CompositeRunner.run(CompositeRunner.java:29)
at org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassRunner$1.runUnprotected(TestClassRunner.java:42)
at org.junit.internal.runners.BeforeAndAfterRunner.runProtected(BeforeAndAfterRunner.java:34)
at org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassRunner.run(TestClassRunner.java:52)
at com.intellij.rt.junit4.Junit4ClassSuite.run(Junit4ClassSuite.java:78)
at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.JUnitStarter.main(JUnitStarter.java:40)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
at com.intellij.rt.execution.application.AppMain.main(AppMain.java:90)

P.S. JUnit 4.1

name: assertEquals(boolean, booean) fails
creator: Freddy Freund
description: Calling assertEquals(boolean, boolean) from Junit 3.8.2 on a pre-Java 5 platform causes a NoSuchMethodError. The cause is that auto-boxing is used in the implementation of this method. The problem does not seem to exist in 3.8.1, where explicit boxing of the boolean arguments is used.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: assertEquals(boolean, booean) fails
rawIssue.dcterms:description: Calling assertEquals(boolean, boolean) from Junit 3.8.2 on a pre-Java 5 platform causes a NoSuchMethodError. The cause is that auto-boxing is used in the implementation of this method. The problem does not seem to exist in 3.8.1, where explicit boxing of the boolean arguments is used.

name: JUnit4 should detect and report if it cannot invoke a method
creator: Rick Yuen
description:
JUnit 4 cannot invoke before, after or test methods if they are not public. However, it does not report this in a very convenient way.

It should either (a) check beforehand if the method is public, or (b) turn off visibility checking in the Method object before invoking the method to allow it to invoke non-public methods.

I think option (b) is preferable.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: JUnit4 should detect and report if it cannot invoke a method
rawIssue.dcterms:description:
JUnit 4 cannot invoke before, after or test methods if they are not public. However, it does not report this in a very convenient way.

It should either (a) check beforehand if the method is public, or (b) turn off visibility checking in the Method object before invoking the method to allow it to invoke non-public methods.

I think option (b) is preferable.

name: JUnit4 don't report nice errors in the test construction
creator: Rick Yuen
description:
When a test class can not be instantiated in Junit 1.4, the error returned say that no test method can be found.
This make it very difficult to find the origin of the problem.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: JUnit4 don't report nice errors in the test construction
rawIssue.dcterms:description:
When a test class can not be instantiated in Junit 1.4, the error returned say that no test method can be found.
This make it very difficult to find the origin of the problem.

name: Handling of SecurityException from suite() method is wrong
creator: Markus Kent
description:
Or at least likely wrong.

If attempting to get the suite() method from a class results in a SecurityException, the current behavior is simply to print a stack trace, which will probably fall over. I haven't figured out an easy way to generate a SecurityException in the tests, so I'm punting this one for now.

creator: Marlene Stamp
description:
JUnit Folks,

Several times in the last week or two, I've tried to access documentation on http://junit.org. Each time, I receive an HTTP 502/Bad Gateway.

Has junit.org been decomissioned? Has it moved?

name: assertEquals array comparison doesn't handle null elements
creator: Rick Yuen
description: Assert.assertEquals(Object[], Object[]) doesn't handle arrays with null element inside. This will cause a NullPointerException.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: assertEquals array comparison doesn't handle null elements
rawIssue.dcterms:description: Assert.assertEquals(Object[], Object[]) doesn't handle arrays with null element inside. This will cause a NullPointerException.

name: assertEquals for "int" and "long" primitives types
creator: Marlene Stamp
description:
I observe that in JUnit 4.0 and JUnit 4.2 an assertEquals call with an int and a long is autoboxed and assertEquals(Object, Object) is called instead (which leads to a different result).

This can cause a problem with JUnit 3.8 migration to JUnit 4.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: assertEquals for "int" and "long" primitives types
rawIssue.dcterms:description:
I observe that in JUnit 4.0 and JUnit 4.2 an assertEquals call with an int and a long is autoboxed and assertEquals(Object, Object) is called instead (which leads to a different result).

This can cause a problem with JUnit 3.8 migration to JUnit 4.

name: javadoc updates for @Ignore in 4.3
creator: Rick Yuen
description: The javadoc of @Ignore annotation needs to reflect the fact that @Ignore can now be used to ignore entire test classes. Added a patch with a possible update of javadoc.

rawIssue.dcterms:title: javadoc updates for @Ignore in 4.3
rawIssue.dcterms:description: The javadoc of @Ignore annotation needs to reflect the fact that @Ignore can now be used to ignore entire test classes. Added a patch with a possible update of javadoc.

name: JUnit 4.3 contains samples and tests in junit-4.3[-src].jar
creator: Jennifer Ginness
description:
The JUnit 4.3 drop contains
- org.junit.samples and
- org.junit.tests
in junit-4.3.jar and junit-4.3-src.jar.

These packages should not be contained in the jars, since they are not necessary for users and they are already contained in junit4.3.zip.

This almost doubles the size of junit-4.3.jar w.r.t 4.2!
